issues.explanation: Although the submission describes a ventilated and heated bonded store, it does not state that manufacturer storage recommendations are followed, nor does it specify temperature/humidity control setpoints, monitoring/recording or actions when limits are exceeded. There is also no information on storage racks strength or that components remain packaged to minimise corrosion/damage. These omissions mean the submission does not fully demonstrate compliance with required storage conditions.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.25 (d): "Storage conditions ensure segregation... The conditions of storage are in accordance with the manufacturer's instructions to prevent deterioration and damage of stored items." AMC 145.A.25 (d)(1)-(3): recommends dry constant temperature, following manufacturer’s storage recommendations, adequate rack strength and keeping components packaged to minimise damage/corrosion.

issues.submission_excerpt:
1.7 MANPOWER RESOURCES

- Quality Manager is on demand contract to meet MOE requirements. Available man-hours; Aircraft Maintenance 7,660 (permanent staff) On demand (contract staff)
issues.explanation: The submission does not provide a documented maintenance man-hour plan as required by 145.A.30(d) (it only gives a single high-level man-hours number and notes a contract Quality Manager). There is no procedure described to reassess work when actual staff availability is reduced, no quarterly review or review frequency, and no demonstration that the proportion of employed vs contracted staff meets AMC1 145.A.30(d)(1). This makes compliance with the man-hour planning and shortfall/mitigation requirements unclear and a regulatory/safety risk.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.30(d): "The organisation shall have a maintenance man-hour plan... In addition, the organisation shall have a procedure to reassess the work intended to be carried out when the actual staff availability is reduced compared to the planned staffing level..." (see also AMC1 145.A.30(d)(1),(2),(7),(9) requiring detail on employed/contracted proportions, inclusion of all activities, 3-month review and a reassessment/mitigation procedure).

issues.submission_excerpt:
## 3.14 COMPETENCE ASSESSMENT OF PERSONNEL

## 3.14.1 Personnel to be Assessed in Accordance with Part 145.A.30 (e)

The Organization shall establish and control competency of the following personnel when employed or contracted by the Organization. - Maintenance Manager Quality Manager Certifying Staff - Mechanics Planning/Technical Records/Stores Staff

## 3.14.2 Assessment Procedure

The following personnel will carry out the competency assessment
issues.explanation: The submission lists categories to be assessed but provides no competency assessment procedure content (no identification of responsible persons, timing of assessments, methods for initial/continuous assessment, crediting prior assessments, validation of records, actions if assessment unsatisfactory, or how results are recorded). AMC2 145.A.30(e) requires the procedure to specify these elements; the lack of these details means the organisation has not demonstrated a compliant competency-assessment system.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.30(e): "The organisation shall establish and control the competency of the personnel... in accordance with a procedure..."; AMC2 145.A.30(e) lists required procedure elements (who is responsible, when assessments occur, how to validate records, means/methods for initial and continuous assessment, how to record results, actions if not satisfactory).

issues.submission_excerpt:
## 3.13 HUMAN FACTORS TRAINING PROCEDURE

## 3.13.2 Categories of Staff to be Trained

HF Training is targeted for all Company certifying staff and quality staff. New starters shall be trained on HF within six months of joining the Organization unless they have completed satisfactory HF training at a previous organization.
issues.explanation: The HF/safety training scope is limited to certifying and quality staff, whereas 145.A.30(e) and AMC4 require safety (including human factors) training appropriate to the individual's responsibilities and list a much wider range of personnel (nominated persons, line managers, supervisors, planners, mechanics, specialised services, stores, purchasing, ground equipment operators, compliance/safety personnel etc.). Limiting training to only certifying and quality staff is therefore incomplete and non-compliant.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.30(e): "The organisation shall establish and control the competency... competency must include an understanding of the application of safety management principles, including human factors..."; AMC4 145.A.30(e) and GM1 145.A.30(e) specify required categories and syllabus coverage for initial and recurrent safety/human factors training.

issues.submission_excerpt:
## 3.6 QUALITY AUDIT PERSONNEL

## 3.6.1 Nominated Personnel

The audit personnel resources at the Organization’s facility are limited to the Quality Manager. The Quality Manager allocates approximately 8 hours per month including performance of audits.

## 1.4.2 Quality Manager

The Quality Manager is responsible for establishing an independent quality assurance system to monitor compliance of the Part 145 Organization with EASA requirements. - He shall have direct access to the Accountable Manager on matters concerning the quality system. - He is responsible for implementing a quality audit programme ... - He is responsible for issue/renewal/cancellation of certifying staff authorizations. - He is responsible for assessing suppliers ... - He is responsible for defect analysis ... - He is responsible for assessing contractors ...
issues.explanation: The MOE does not clearly nominate separate persons for the compliance monitoring function and the safety management function, nor document their independence. The Quality Manager is performing multiple roles (audits/compliance monitoring and tasks such as issuing certifying staff authorisations and supplier/contractor assessments) and is allocated only ~8 hours/month for audit activity. AMC1 requires the compliance monitoring manager to be independent from maintenance functions, have sufficient time/resources, access to all parts (including subcontractors), and not be one of the nominated maintenance persons; the submission does not demonstrate compliance with these independence, nomination, access or resourcing requirements.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.30(b),(c),(ca): accountable manager shall nominate persons for maintenance functions, compliance monitoring and safety management; nominated persons shall have responsibility to and direct access to the accountable manager. AMC1 145.A.30(c)(ca)(b)(2) states the compliance monitoring manager should not be one of the persons in 145.A.30(b), must have appropriate experience, and have access to all parts of the organisation; AMC1 145.A.30(c)(ca)(d)-(e) address resourcing and independence.

issues.submission_excerpt:
## 1.6 LIST OF CERTIFYING STAFF AND B1 AND B2 SUPPORT STAFF

## 1.6.1 Certifying Staff List

A list of certifying staff is held and maintained by the Quality Manager. This list is approved by the Quality Manager and forwarded to the Authority as described in section 1.11 of this MOE.
issues.explanation: 145.A.30(h)(1)(ii) requires the organisation to maintain a register of category B1 and B2 support staff used to support category C certifying staff. The submission references a certifying staff list but does not explicitly confirm the existence or content of a dedicated register for B1/B2 support staff (e.g., for base maintenance support), nor details of how it is maintained and made available to the authority.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.30(h)(1)(ii): "The organisation shall maintain a register of any such category B1 and B2 support staff."

issues.submission_excerpt: He is responsible for issue/renewal/cancellation of certifying staff authorizations.
issues.explanation: The MOE names the Quality Manager as responsible for issuing/renewing authorisations but contains no documented procedure or reference in the cited sections that describes how competency is assessed prior to issue or re-issue. 145.A.35(a) and (f) require the organisation to ensure certifying/support staff have adequate understanding and to assess prospective certifying staff in accordance with a procedure in the MOE; AMC 145.A.35(a)(4) explicitly expects the assessment to be conducted per an MOE procedure. The exposition therefore lacks the procedural detail required to demonstrate compliance before authorisation is granted.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.35(a) and (f): organisation shall ensure certifying/support staff have adequate understanding and shall assess all prospective certifying staff in accordance with a procedure as specified in the MOE. AMC 145.A.35(a)(4): assessment of competency should be conducted in accordance with a procedure approved by the competent authority (item 3.9 of the MOE).

issues.submission_excerpt: Certifying Staff Records Contents Records will contain as a minimum the following information: - Name* - Date of birth - Basic training - Type training Continuation training - Experience Qualifications relevant to the approval Scope of the authorization* - Date of first issue of the authorization - If appropriate – expiry date of the authorization* - Identification number of the authorization* Signature of authorised person* - Results of competency assessment - Recent photograph (*Contained on authorization document)
issues.explanation: The records list captures generic 'Experience' but the MOE does not define, measure or control the specific requirement of 'at least 6 months of actual relevant aircraft or component maintenance experience in any 2-year period' nor does it provide the required procedure for returning staff who do not meet this requirement. 145.A.35(c) requires a specific experience metric and a MOE procedure to ensure competency on return to maintenance; the submission does not implement or reference that procedure or the 6-month/2-year metric.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.35(c): organisation shall ensure certifying/support staff are involved in, on average, at least 6 months of actual relevant aircraft or component maintenance experience in any 2-year period; when not met the organisation shall ensure return-to-work competency in accordance with a procedure included in the MOE.

issues.submission_excerpt: He is responsible for ensuring the competence of all personnel engaged in maintenance by establishing a programme of training and continuation training using internal and external sources.
issues.explanation: While the MOE assigns responsibility for establishing a training/continuation training programme, it does not include a documented programme that lists all certifying/support staff, the timing of training within each 2‑year period, the training elements required (technology, procedures, maintenance data changes, lessons learned) or evidence that training will ensure compliance with Part-66. AMC1 145.A.35(e) expects a programme listing staff, timing and confirmation that training was carried out — this detail is not present in the provided text, creating ambiguity over compliance with the continuation training requirements.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.35(d) and (e): organisation shall ensure all certifying/support staff receive sufficient continuation training in each 2‑year period covering technology, procedures and human factors; organisation shall establish a programme for continuation training and include a procedure to ensure compliance with 145.A.35 and Annex III (Part-66). AMC1 145.A.35(e): programme should list all certifying/support staff, when training will take place, elements of training and indication training was completed on time.

issues.submission_excerpt: Certifying staff are issued with personal authorization forms by the Quality Manager. A copy of this document will be retained in the certifying staff records.
issues.explanation: The MOE states that personal authorisation forms are issued and retained, but contains no explicit statement or procedural link that the authorisation's validity and scope are limited to the scope and validity of the holder's Part‑66 licence, nor a procedure to verify licence validity before issuing or renewing authorisations. 145.A.35(b) and (g) require authorisations not to exceed the licence scope and to be limited to the licence validity; the submission does not demonstrate this required linkage.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.35(b) and (g): organisation may only issue certification authorisation where the scope does not exceed the scope of the Part‑66 licence; where privileges are to be exercised the organisation shall issue an authorisation that clearly specifies scope and limits and whose validity is limited to the validity of the aircraft maintenance licence on which it is based.

issues.submission_excerpt: Certifying Staff Records Contents Records will contain as a minimum the following information: - Name* - Date of birth - Basic training - Type training Continuation training - Experience Qualifications relevant to the approval Scope of the authorization* - Date of first issue of the authorization - If appropriate – expiry date of the authorization* - Identification number of the authorization* Signature of authorised person* - Results of competency assessment - Recent photograph (*Contained on authorization document)
issues.explanation: The record list omits any reference to 'details of any airworthiness review staff qualification or authorisation', required by 145.A.35(j)(4). If the organisation holds airworthiness review staff (ARS) qualifications or authorisations, those details must be included in certifying/support staff records; the omission is a non‑compliance or, at minimum, an incomplete record-keeping procedure.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.35(j)(4): the organisation shall maintain a record of all certifying staff and support staff which shall contain details of any airworthiness review staff qualification or authorisation.

issues.submission_excerpt: Tooling and equipment may be sourced from original equipment manufacturers or any other source that can meet the Organizations’ requirements. This may be via an outright purchase or rental or lease agreement.
issues.explanation: The submission allows sourcing tools by rental/lease but does not state that availability of rented/leased equipment is guaranteed in the MOE by detailed contracts/lease agreements, nor does it state the default requirement for permanent availability. This omits the specific MOE/contractual assurance required by 145.A.40(a)(1) and creates a risk that leased items may not be contractually guaranteed when needed.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.40(a)(1): "Where necessary, equipment and tools shall be permanently available, except in the case of availability of the equipment and tools being guaranteed in the MOE by detailed contracts or lease agreements."

issues.submission_excerpt: Personal items of tooling or equipment that are subject to testing or calibration requirements may be used in aircraft maintenance performed under the Organization’s Part 145 approval, provided the controls required under section 2.5 of this Exposition are adhered to.
issues.explanation: The text permits use of personal/loaned tools but does not require these items to be entered into the organisation's control register, allocated unique identification, or demonstrably placed under the organisation's control when used. AMC guidance explicitly expects personal tools that the organisation agrees can be used to be identified/listed and controlled; the submission lacks that explicit control mechanism, creating ambiguity over responsibility and traceability.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.40(a)(2): "The availability of equipment and tools means that they are under the control of the organisation. When the tool or equipment is used, the organisation must ensure that the tool or equipment is controlled and serviceable."; AMC 145.A.40 (a): recommends a control register "including any personal tools and equipment that the organisation agrees can be used."

issues.submission_excerpt: All items of tooling and equipment that are subject to calibration are individually identified with an adhesive label indicating the next calibration due date.
issues.explanation: The labelling requirement in the submission only captures the next calibration due date and does not require that labels indicate if the item is unserviceable for any other reason (where not obvious). AMC explicitly requires labelling to show next inspection/service/calibration due and if the item is unserviceable for any other reason; omission may reduce visibility of unserviceable status to users.
issues.legislation_source: AMC 145.A.40 (b)(1): "A clear system of labelling all tooling, equipment and test equipment is therefore necessary giving information on when the next inspection or service or calibration is due and if the item is unserviceable for any other reason where it may not be obvious."

issues.submission_excerpt: - If necessary a current calibration certificate
issues.explanation: The incoming inspection checklist conditions the verification of calibration to "if necessary", which is ambiguous and may permit acceptance of items without confirming calibration status when calibration is required by the approved data. 145.A.40(b) requires tools and test equipment to be controlled and calibrated to an officially recognised standard with records kept; incoming inspection should explicitly verify calibration documentation where the item requires calibration.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.40(b): "The organisation shall ensure that all tools, equipment and particularly test equipment, as appropriate, are controlled and calibrated according to an officially recognised standard at a frequency to ensure serviceability and accuracy. Records of such calibrations and of the standard used shall be kept by the organisation."

issues.submission_excerpt: When a component is removed from an aircraft for any reason, its status shall be clearly identified. This identification shall be by the attachment of a label as detailed in section 5 of this Exposition.
issues.explanation: The Exposition requires classification of components into the categories in 145.A.42(a) and appropriate segregation (145.A.42(c)), but the submission only describes labelling of removed components and does not define the required component classification scheme, nor formal segregation/segregated storage areas or procedures to segregate serviceable, unserviceable and unsalvageable items. This omission means the organisation has not documented how it meets the specific classification and segregation requirements of the regulation.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.42(a) — "All components shall be classified and appropriately segregated into the following categories..."; 145.A.42(c) — "Unserviceable components shall be identified and stored in a secure location under the control of the organisation..." (full text: 145.A.42(a) and 145.A.42(c), Annex I (Part‑145))

issues.submission_excerpt: The person removing the component shall annotate the following information on the label: Part Number and Serial Number (if applicable) Description, time in service, TSO and TSN (if known) - Aircraft Registration and date of removal - Reason for Removal - Defect if applicable
issues.explanation: AMC1 requires that unserviceable components be clearly declared on a tag 'together with the component identification data and any information that is useful' and that means be provided to prevent unintentional separation of the tag. The submission lists label data but contains no requirement or method to prevent tag separation (e.g. permanent tie, rivet, tamper‑evident fastener or procedure), creating a risk that identification tags could become detached and the component status lost.
issues.legislation_source: AMC1 145.A.42(a)(ii)(a) — unserviceable status should be clearly declared on a tag with identification and useful information; 'Means should be provided to prevent unintentional separation of this tag from the component.'

issues.submission_excerpt:
These suppliers must have a capability to supply the required product and/or service and issue or provide traceability to an authorised release document or certificate of conformity for that product/service.

It will be the responsibility of the person placing the purchase order to ensure the supplier details are correct and that a description of the type of goods or service required from the supplier is recorded on the
issues.explanation: 145.A.42(b) requires documented procedures that specify the persons in charge of acceptance, the sources and verification to be carried out, handling & storage, and how cases where an EASA Form 1/equivalent is not available are controlled. The submission does not identify the persons formally authorised to accept components, nor does it provide a procedure for control when an EASA Form 1 (or equivalent) is not available — it only states supplier expectations and places informal responsibility on the purchaser. This is incomplete and does not meet the procedural detail mandated by the rule.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.42(b)2 — procedures shall specify: (i) the persons in charge of the acceptance of components, standard parts and materials; (ii) the sources from which components may be accepted, and the verification to be carried out; (iii) handling and storage; (iv) the cases where the EASA Form 1 or equivalent may not be available, and the way to control those cases.

issues.submission_excerpt:
Apart from the details recorded on the purchase order, the Organization does not retain supplier or subcontractor information.

At this time the Organization does not maintain suppliers and subcontractors’ files.
issues.explanation: 145.A.42(b)(4) requires that the organisation keep records of the acceptance of components, standard parts and materials and of the related conformity/airworthiness statements and release certificates. The submission explicitly states that, beyond purchase order details, supplier/subcontractor information and files are not retained — this is insufficient and fails to ensure traceability and record retention of release documents and conformity statements.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.42(b)4 — "The organisation shall keep records of the acceptance of components, standard parts and materials, and of the related conformity or airworthiness statements and release certificates."

issues.submission_excerpt: NAA certified suppliers and International Standard accredited suppliers would automatically be acceptable without further assessment.
issues.explanation: GM3 states that suppliers certified to recognised standards may be acceptable but 'the use of such suppliers does not exempt the organisation from its obligations under 145.A.42' and supplier evaluation should consider specific elements. The submission's policy to accept such suppliers 'automatically' without further assessment is weaker than the guidance and risks bypassing supplier checks (shelf‑life control, handling, traceability, procedures for electrostatic devices, etc.).
issues.legislation_source: GM3 145.A.42(b)(i)(b) & GM3 145.A.42(b)(i)(a) — supplier certification may be considered but does not remove the organisation's obligation to ensure incoming components meet 145.A.42; GM3 lists elements that should be considered for initial and recurrent supplier evaluation.

issues.submission_excerpt: An assessment of parts supplied for fitment to aircraft shall be limited to an incoming inspection as detailed in section 2.2 of this Exposition.
issues.explanation: The Exposition references an incoming inspection (section 2.2) but the supplied excerpt does not include the content of section 2.2 or the required incoming inspection detail (physical checks, shelf‑life, packaging, plugs/caps, ESD protection, etc.). As written, the acceptance process is ambiguous and does not demonstrate the organisation performs the comprehensive incoming inspections described in GM1/AMC1, which is necessary to ensure components are in satisfactory condition.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.42(b)(i) & GM1 145.A.42(b)(i) — organisation procedures for acceptance should be based upon incoming inspections including physical inspection and review of documentation; GM1 lists typical incoming inspection checks (condition, shelf life, packaging, plugs/caps, ESD, batch traceability).

issues.submission_excerpt:
The component will be returned to the dispatch area in stores and placed on the appropriate shelf or if too large, on the floor adjacent to stores, to await dispatch paperwork.

During storage of unserviceable components the following actions will be performed: Components must be properly blanked ESD requirements shall be complied with as required - Fire bottle cartridges will be made safe - Nitrogen and oxygen bottles will be discharged to the minimum specified pressure Shock struts will discharged of gaseous contents - Requirements of the aircraft/engine component maintenance manual to be complied with Components protected as necessary - Wheel and tyre assemblies will be stored at a pressure not to exceed 50 psi
issues.explanation: 145.A.42(d) and (e) require that unserviceable and unsalvageable components be stored in a secure location under the control of the organisation and that unsalvageable items are prevented from re‑entering the component supply system (mutilation or documented transfer). The submission describes general storage actions but does not define 'secure location under control' (access control, segregation of unsalvageable items), nor procedures for preventing re‑entry or for mutilation/traceable disposal or notification to the competent authority when transferring unsalvageable components for training/research as required by the rule.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.42(d)1 & 145.A.42(e)1-4 — unserviceable components must be stored in a secure location under the organisation's control until a decision is made; unsalvageable components must be prevented from re‑entering the supply system, retained securely until permanently mutilated/destroyed, except transfers for training/research with competent authority notification and traceable records.

issues.submission_excerpt: He is responsible for availability of all necessary maintenance data as required by Part 145.A.45.
issues.explanation: The submission assigns responsibility for availability of maintenance data but contains no MOE procedure for modifying maintenance instructions as required by 145.A.45(d). There is no documented process for demonstrating equivalent or improved maintenance standards, performing a risk assessment or practical demonstration, providing paper/electronic traceability, approving the modification, or informing the type‑certificate holder as required by AMC1 145.A.45(d).
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.45(d): "The organisation may only modify maintenance instructions in accordance with a procedure specified in the MOE. ... the organisation shall demonstrate that it results in equivalent or improved maintenance standards, and shall inform the type‑certificate holder of the modification." AMC1 145.A.45(d): requires practical demonstration, possible risk assessment, approval by compliance monitoring personnel, traceability and informing the author/type‑certificate holder.

issues.submission_excerpt: He will ensure that any observed non-compliances or poor standards are brought to the attention of the Maintenance Manager. - He is responsible for follow up and closure of any non-conformances identified. The Quality Manager will establish regular meetings with the Accountable Manager to apprise him of the effectiveness of the quality system. This will include details of any reported discrepancy not being adequately addressed by the relevant person or in respect of any disagreement concerning the nature of a discrepancy. He is responsible for preparing standard practices and procedures (MOE, including the associated procedure(s) for use within the organization and ensuring their adequacy regarding Part 145 and any amendments to the Regulation.
issues.explanation: While the Quality Manager duties reference non‑conformances and reporting within the organisation, there is no explicit procedure to record and notify the author of maintenance data when inaccurate, incomplete or ambiguous maintenance data is discovered, nor is there a requirement to retain records of such communications as AMC1 145.A.45(c)(1) recommends (e.g. via the internal safety reporting scheme).
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.45(c): "The organisation shall establish procedures to ensure that if inaccurate, incomplete or ambiguous procedures, practices, information or maintenance instructions are found in the maintenance data, they are recorded and notified to the author of the maintenance data." AMC1 145.A.45(c)(1): procedure should record discovery via internal safety reporting scheme and notify the author with retention of records until clarification/amendment is received.

issues.submission_excerpt: Operator’s Data Most of the Organizations’ customers have contracted the maintenance and control of their aircraft’s status to third party companies specialized on computerized maintenance tracking such as CAMP. This responsibility for information retrieval lies with the customer together with their contracted maintenance tracking companies. An operator may wish to give the Company direct access to his maintenance data. This is generally through electronic access. This access may be limited in time and/or to “read only” or “read and update” access. The operator must give his instructions in writing to these companies before they will allow the Organization access to the data of their aircraft. Organization’s Computerized records No software programmes are currently used by the Organization, all work-packs are scanned on completion on to the maintenance computer.
issues.explanation: The submission delegates amendment/retrieval responsibility to customers and third parties and indicates no in‑house software or process beyond scanning completed workpacks. There is no documented procedure to monitor amendment status, perform regular amendment checks, or subscribe to amendment schemes as required by 145.A.45(g) and AMC1 (g), so the organisation cannot demonstrate it keeps maintenance data up to date.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.45(g): "The organisation shall establish a procedure to ensure that maintenance data is kept up to date. In the case of a subscriber to maintenance data, the procedure shall specify that the check for amendments is carried out on a regular basis." AMC1 145.A.45(g): recommends a procedure to monitor amendment status and ensure all amendments are received (subscriber responsibilities).

issues.submission_excerpt: The following document constitute a work package: MF 012 Cover Sheet – provides details of work order number; planned start and end date; location; aircraft details; customer; warranty / parts programme information; AD status; maintenance programme reference; other related information. MF 015 Specimen signature sheet - MF 014 Work sheet index - MF 013 Work sheet – provides details of defect / task; records action taken; parts used; space for critical or independent inspection; signature block.
issues.explanation: The submission lists work‑package forms and some fields but does not specify that work cards/worksheets will either transcribe the applicable maintenance data (ADs, IPCs, manufacturer tasks) or make precise references to the exact maintenance task(s) per 145.A.45(e). It also lacks requirements ensuring work cards differentiate disassembly/accomplishment/reassembly/testing or that data is available to staff before maintenance and in close proximity as AMC/145.A.45(e) and (f) require.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.45(e): organisation shall provide a common work card/worksheet system and either transcribe applicable maintenance data or make precise reference to the maintenance task(s); 145.A.45(f): "The organisation shall ensure that all applicable maintenance data is readily available for use when required by maintenance personnel." AMC1 145.A.45(e)(2-3), AMC 145.A.45(f)(1-2): work cards should differentiate disassembly/reassembly/testing, consider human factors and ensure data availability/adequate number of terminals or paper copies near the aircraft.

issues.submission_excerpt: The shift structure is designed to ensure an overlap of personnel to assure continuity of maintenance responsibility and awareness.
issues.explanation: The submission focuses on personnel overlap but contains no documented system or procedure to plan availability of tools, equipment, material, maintenance data or facilities as required by 145.A.47(a). AMC guidance expects planning to cover logistics, inventory control, man-hours estimation and facility availability; these elements are not addressed, creating a compliance gap and operational risk if required resources are unavailable.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.47 (a): "The organisation shall have a system appropriate to the amount and complexity of work to plan the availability of all necessary personnel, tools, equipment, material, maintenance data and facilities in order to ensure the safe completion of the maintenance work."

issues.submission_excerpt: Each shift is rostered 14 days on andf 14 days off
issues.explanation: The submission specifies long shift rostering (including 12-hour shifts and extended multi-day rostering) but provides no evidence of fatigue risk assessment, advance publication of schedules, fatigue-mitigation measures, or a procedure for significant changes to working hours. AMC/GM require consideration of fatigue in planning, safety policy inclusion, reporting, risk assessment and mitigations (e.g. additional supervision, limited critical tasks, extra rest breaks), none of which are documented here.
issues.legislation_source: AMC1 145.A.47 (b) (a)-(d) and GM1 145.A.47(b): organisation should consider threat of fatigue in planning/organising shifts, include fatigue in safety policy and reporting, perform risk assessment for significant increases/changes in hours, and define mitigations (additional supervision, limitation to non-critical tasks, use of additional rest breaks).

issues.submission_excerpt: When a task is required to be handed over from one shift to the oncoming shift, the shift engineer handing over the task shall ensure that, as required, all work that has been accomplished on the off going shift has been signed for or certified on the maintenance records.
issues.explanation: This handover wording only addresses internal shift-to-shift handovers and signatures on maintenance records; it does not establish the procedure required by 145.A.47(c) for temporarily or permanently transferring maintenance tasks to another organisation. There is no documented process to ensure tasks transferred are performed by appropriately approved organisations, carried out to the correct maintenance data, or that all necessary information is provided to the external organisation.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.47 (c): "When it is required to temporarily or permanently transfer maintenance tasks to another organisation, the organisation shall establish a procedure to ensure... (1) performed by organisations appropriately approved; (2) carried out in accordance with the maintenance data referred to in point 145.A.45; (3) all necessary information for the performance of the maintenance tasks is made available to the organisation that performs them."

issues.submission_excerpt: Any outstanding work for specific tasks is to be recorded in a specific “Handover Email” to the oncoming shift engineer. The engineer coming on shift shall reply with questions if any handover information requires to be clarified. The same e-mail string is used for each handover but shall a new email shall be generated at each weekly handover. This email shall provide a record of the shift handover tasks.
issues.explanation: Relying solely on an email string is not a formalised handover process as described in AMC 145.A.47(c); there is no requirement for a planned shift overlap, face-to-face exchange, structured checklist, or verification that the incoming person has understood the information. This increases the risk of incomplete communication and misunderstanding during critical handovers.
issues.legislation_source: AMC 145.A.47 (c): "The primary objective of the changeover / handover information is to ensure effective communication... Effective task and shift handover depends on three basic elements: outgoing person's ability to understand and communicate; incoming person's ability to understand and assimilate; a formalised process for exchanging information and a planned shift overlap and a place for such exchanges to take place."

issues.submission_excerpt: Cleaning Programme The requirements for the control of FO during maintenance operations shall include but not be limited to the following: - All material and components upon receipt and prior to movement around the facility shall be inspected for the correct fitment of protective coverings and blanks, to prevent any foreign object damage or contamination. On completion of assembly operations, components shall be cleaned or flushed and inspected to ensure freedom from debris, prior to applying protective covers, blanks etc. - Prior to installation components will be checked for foreign object ingress before installing in the aircraft.
issues.explanation: The submission describes FOD prevention and pre-installation checks but does not contain an explicit procedure requiring a post-maintenance general verification that the aircraft or component is clear of all tools, equipment and extraneous parts nor a requirement that removed access panels are refitted before release to service. This omission means the organisation has not demonstrated compliance with the explicit post-maintenance verification required by 145.A.48(a).
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.48 (a): "after completion of maintenance, a general verification is carried out to ensure that the aircraft or component is clear of all tools, equipment and any other extraneous parts and material, and that all access panels removed have been refitted;"

issues.submission_excerpt: A critical task includes but is not limited to the following: - Inspection of chip detectors on multi-engine aircraft S.O.A.P. checks on multi-engine aircraft - Refitting of oil filler caps on multi-engine aircraft - Refitting of more than one wheel and tyre assemblies on an axle and/or brake units - Refitting of crew seats
issues.explanation: The submission provides a non-exhaustive list of critical tasks but does not describe a documented procedure using the specified data sources (design approval holder, accident reports, occurrence reporting, audits, flight data, etc.) to identify and review critical maintenance tasks, nor does it state that an error-capturing method is implemented after any critical maintenance task. This fails to meet 145.A.48(b) and AMC guidance requiring identification processes and guaranteed application of error-capturing methods.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.48 (b): "an error-capturing method is implemented after the performance of any critical maintenance task;" and AMC1/AMC2 145.A.48(c)(2): organisation should have a procedure to identify the error-capturing methods, the critical maintenance tasks, the training and the qualifications of staff applying error-capturing methods and which data sources (e.g. design approval holder, accident reports, occurrence reporting, audits, flight data) are used to identify critical tasks.

issues.submission_excerpt: An independent inspection shall be carried out after any flight safety sensitive maintenance task has been carried out. The manufactures instructions for continued airworthiness should be followed when determining the need for an independent inspection.
issues.explanation: The submission mandates independent inspections in general terms but does not define the ‘independent qualified person’, their required training/experience, the prohibition on the independent inspector issuing the release to service, nor the requirement that the work card records identification of both the authorised person and the independent qualified person and details of the inspection before the certificate is issued. These omissions mean the organisation has not implemented the full AMC4 requirements for independent inspections and associated records.
issues.legislation_source: AMC4 145.A.48(c)(2)(a)-(c): defines independent inspection, requires an 'independent qualified person' (trained and experienced), states the independent qualified person attests satisfactory completion but does not issue the certificate of release to service, requires the authorised person to issue the certificate after independent inspection, and requires the work card system to record identification of both persons and details of the inspection.

issues.submission_excerpt: Where only one person is available to carry out and certify these tasks then that person shall perform a separate re-inspection after task completion of all the same tasks. An entry on the work card stating “CRITICAL TASK INSPECTION” shall be entered and certified.
issues.explanation: The submission allows re‑inspection whenever only one person is available, but AMC4 restricts reinspection as an error‑capturing method to unforeseen circumstances only and prohibits its routine use when an independent qualified person should have been assigned to the station/shift. The submission also does not require the detailed reinspection recording (identification and reinspection details) prior to issuing the certificate of release as required by AMC4. This leaves risk of inappropriate routine use of reinspection and inadequate records.
issues.legislation_source: AMC4 145.A.48(c)(2)(d): reinspection is only permitted in unforeseen circumstances when only one person is available; the circumstances cannot be considered unforeseen if a suitable independent qualified person has not been assigned; the work card must record identification and details of the reinspection before the certificate of release is issued.

issues.submission_excerpt: The Encouragement of Reporting The aim of the Organization’s error management system is to encourage the free and frank reporting of maintenance errors by personnel with the objective of identifying the factors contributing to maintenance errors and to make the system resistant to similar errors. A Code of Practice The following procedures represent the code of practice to reduce hazards and risks from maintenance errors. The Organization operates a confidential reporting system to allow personnel to identify specific maintenance safety issues that warrant further attention.
issues.explanation: The submission focuses on occurrence/reporting and reinspection but does not describe specific error‑capturing methods (e.g. visual inspection, operational checks, functional tests, rigging checks) or criteria to ensure those methods are adequate for the work and system disturbance as required by AMC3. Without documented, task‑appropriate error‑capturing methods the organisation cannot demonstrate effective detection of maintenance errors.
issues.legislation_source: AMC3 145.A.48(c)(2): "Error‑capturing methods are those actions defined by the organisation to detect maintenance errors... The organisation should ensure that the error‑capturing methods are adequate for the work and the disturbance of the system. A combination of several actions (e.g. visual inspection, operational check, functional test, rigging check) may be necessary in some cases."

issues.submission_excerpt: The certificate of release to service statement shall be as follows: “Certifies that the work specified except as otherwise specified was carried out in accordance with Part 145 and in respect to that work the aircraft/aircraft component is considered ready for release to service.”
issues.explanation: The submission reproduces the recommended certification statement but does not require or show that the Organisation's Part-145 approval number and the identity of the person issuing the release will be included on the certificate, as AMC 145.A.50(b)(1) requires. There is also an incomplete sentence later about the certifying signature which creates ambiguity about mandatory inclusion of the approval reference and issuer identity on the release.
issues.legislation_source: AMC 145.A.50(b)(1): certificate should contain the statement and should reference the EASA Part-145 approval number and the identity of the person who issued the release.

issues.submission_excerpt:
2.18.3 Mandatory Reporting Procedure

To comply with Regulation (EU) No 376/2014 art 4(1) all occurrences falling under 1.8.7.2 subjects shall be reported to the Quality Manager using the Safety Occurrence Report Form. Personnel shall report occurrences within 72 hours of becoming aware of the occurrence, unless exceptional circumstances prevent this. Following notification of an occurrence, the Quality Manager shall report to the CAA the details of occurrences collected as soon as possible and in any event no later than 72 hours after becoming aware of the occurrence.
issues.explanation: 145.A.50(c) requires that new defects or incomplete maintenance work identified during maintenance be brought to the attention of the aircraft operator specifically to obtain agreement to rectify or to defer completion, with the operator informed if they decline. The submission's reporting procedure addresses internal/CAA reporting timelines but does not define the required immediate operator notification process during maintenance, nor how operator agreement to rectify or defer will be obtained and recorded.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.50(c): "New defects or incomplete maintenance work orders identified during the maintenance shall be brought to the attention of the aircraft operator for the specific purpose of obtaining agreement to rectify such defects or to defer the completion of the maintenance work orders. If the aircraft operator declines to have such maintenance carried out, point (e) applies."

issues.submission_excerpt: The Part 145.A.50 Certificate of Release to Service for completed maintenance is a certification for completion of the programmed work package, together with additional work arising. This certification is a declaration of satisfactory work clearance in each applicable category, signifying that all work required has been actioned. This permits the aircraft to be released to service.
issues.explanation: 145.A.50(e) permits issuance of a release when the organisation is unable to complete all ordered maintenance, but only if a MOE procedure approved by the competent authority is followed and the fact of deferment is entered on the aircraft certificate of release to service. The submission describes only release after completed maintenance and provides no MOE procedure for issuing a release when maintenance is incomplete, no requirement for competent authority approval of that procedure, nor any statement that deferments will be entered on the certificate as required.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.50(e): organisation may issue a certificate of release to service within approved aircraft limitations when unable to complete all ordered maintenance, provided the MOE procedure (approved by the competent authority) is followed and the organisation enters such fact in the aircraft certificate of release to service before issue. AMC1 145.A.50(e) further explains requirements for informing the person responsible for continuing airworthiness and documenting deferments.

issues.submission_excerpt: - All items used in the maintenance activity must have been released to the requirements of the Authority and as detailed in section 2.2 of this Exposition. All Parts must be traceable by the GRN, which must be recorded on the maintenance document.
issues.explanation: 145.A.50(d) and its AMCs set detailed requirements for issuing an Authorised Release Certificate (EASA Form 1) for components maintained off the aircraft, including specific entries (e.g. Block 11, 12, 14b), statements of limitations, maintenance history, AD/repair/modification status and procedures for stored/used/unapproved-maintained components. The submission addresses part traceability but lacks any documented procedure for issuing EASA Form 1s, required block content/remarks, handling of components removed from other aircraft or from storage, and acceptance/testing processes described in AMC2 for issuing an EASA Form 1.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.50(d): "A certificate of release to service shall be issued at the completion of any maintenance on a component when it is off the aircraft. The certificate ... shall be the 'Authorised Release Certificate' (EASA Form 1) ... issued in accordance with the requirements of Appendix II." AMC1/AMC2 145.A.50(d) detail EASA Form 1 content (blocks 11/12/14b), acceptance, inspection, life status, AD/repair/modification listing and procedures for stored/used/unapproved-maintained components.

issues.submission_excerpt: The following regulation shall apply when performing certification actions: - All work will be carried out in accordance with and cross referenced to data approved or accepted by the Authority or by an organisation approved or accepted by the Authority.
issues.explanation: 145.A.50(f) permits temporary fitting of components without an appropriate release certificate under strict conditions (maximum 30 flight hours, operator agreement, certificate of conformity or removed-from-aircraft-found-serviceable, organisation approval, and issuance of a release specifying acceptance conditions and limitations). The submission does not contain a procedure addressing temporary fitting, operator agreement, acceptance criteria for such components, issuance of a certificate specifying limitations, or removal within the 30-flight-hour limit, creating non-conformance with the derogation conditions.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.50(f): permits temporary fitting of a component without the appropriate release certificate for max 30 flight hours or until return to main base, subject to aircraft operator agreement, component having a certificate of conformity or removed from another aircraft and found serviceable, organisation approval, and issuance of a certificate of release specifying conditions and limitations. AMC1 145.A.50(f) clarifies what a suitable release certificate and compliance mean.

issues.submission_excerpt: Should the Organization terminates its operation, all retained hard copy maintenance records covering the last two years shall be distributed to the last owner or customer of the respective aircraft or component or shall be stored as specified by the CAA.
issues.explanation: This statement conflicts with 145.A.55(c) which requires distribution or storage of retained maintenance records covering the last three years when the organisation terminates operations. Limiting distribution to 'the last two years' is non-compliant and risks loss of required historical records.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.55(c): "The organisation shall retain a copy of all maintenance records and any associated maintenance data for 3 years ... Where an organisation approved under this Annex terminates its operation, all retained maintenance records covering the last 3 years shall be distributed to the last owner or customer ... or shall be stored as specified by the competent authority."

issues.submission_excerpt: Applicable records for owner / operators shall include but not be limited to the following: - Certificates of Release to Service for the work carried out
issues.explanation: The submission lists CRS as a record for operators but does not state that the organisation will provide a copy of each Certificate of Release to Service to the aircraft operator together with any specific maintenance data used for repairs or modifications. 145.A.55(b) requires explicit provision of the CRS and associated specific maintenance data to the operator; the procedure is silent on this required action.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.55(b): "The organisation shall provide a copy of each certificate of release to service to the aircraft operator, together with a copy of any specific maintenance data used for repairs or modifications performed."

issues.submission_excerpt: Computer backup discs, etc. shall be stored in accordance with section 2.14.6 of this Exposition.
issues.explanation: The submission defers backup storage details to another section but does not specify required safeguards such as at least one backup updated within 24 hours, storage in a different location from working media, or specific protections against damage, alteration and theft as required by AMC1/145.A.55(c) and 145.A.55(c). This omission creates ambiguity about whether the backups meet regulatory standards.
issues.legislation_source: AMC1 145.A.55 (c) / 145.A.55(c): "Computer record systems should have at least one backup system, which should be updated within 24 hours of any new entry. ... Computer backup discs, tapes etc. shall be stored in a different location ... in an environment that ensures they remain in good condition."

issues.submission_excerpt: The Maintenance Manager shall ensure that the data provided on the owner / operator supplied work card / work sheet reflects the latest revision of the detailed airworthiness data.
issues.explanation: The procedure requires checking that owner/operator supplied cards reflect the latest revision, but there is no general requirement that the maintenance record itself records the revision status of the approved maintenance data used. AMC1 145.A.55(a)(3) expects maintenance records to refer to the revision status of the data used; the submission is therefore incomplete and may impede traceability of the data used for maintenance actions.
issues.legislation_source: AMC1 145.A.55 (a)(3): "Maintenance records should refer to the revision status of the data used."  (145.A.55(a) also requires records sufficient to prove requirements met for CRS and airworthiness review.)

issues.submission_excerpt: For certification activities under the Organization’s Part 145 authorization, the certifying staff’s personal signature and stamp will be used for certification of individual work items.
issues.explanation: The manual describes use of signatures/stamps for certification but contains no record-keeping detail for certifying staff or airworthiness review staff (e.g. name, DOB, training, experience, authorisation scope/ID, dates of issue/expiry) as listed in AMC1/AMC2 145.A.55(d). Absence of this staff records policy risks non-compliance and reduces the organisation's ability to demonstrate staff competence and authorisations during oversight.
issues.legislation_source: AMC1 145.A.55 (d) and AMC2 145.A.55 (d): list of minimum staff-record information (name; date of birth; basic/task/recurrent training; experience; qualifications; scope of authorisation; date of first issue; expiry date; identification number; and for airworthiness review staff, certifying staff authorisation and relevant experience).

issues.submission_excerpt: No software programmes are currently used by the Organization, all work-packs are scanned on completion on to the maintenance computer.
issues.explanation: The submission states records are scanned onto a maintenance computer but provides no controls for access, minimum authorised-user rules, audit trail, protection against unauthorised alteration, nor any statement of retrieval/organisational arrangement to ensure records are 'accessible within a reasonable time' as required by AMC1 145.A.55(a) and safeguards required by AMC1 145.A.55(c). This creates ambiguity about integrity, confidentiality and retrievability of electronic records.
issues.legislation_source: AMC1 145.A.55 (a): "The record-keeping system should ensure that all records are accessible within a reasonable time ... organised to ensure their traceability and retrievability." AMC1 145.A.55 (c): "Computer record systems should include safeguards to prevent unauthorised personnel from altering the data."

issues.submission_excerpt: Following notification of an occurrence, the Quality Manager shall report to the CAA the details of occurrences collected as soon as possible and in any event no later than 72 hours after becoming aware of the occurrence.
issues.explanation: The excerpt shows procedures only for reporting to the CAA; there is no procedure described for reporting to the organisation responsible for the type design (manufacturer / design approval holder) or to the aircraft operator as required when a condition has resulted or may result in an unsafe condition that seriously endangers flight safety. This omission fails to meet 145.A.60(d)'s explicit requirement to notify those parties.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.60(d): "The organisation shall report to the competent authority, to the organisation responsible for the type design or supplemental type design, and to the operator of the aircraft, any condition of an aircraft or component identified by the organisation, which has resulted or may result in an unsafe condition that seriously endangers flight safety. The organisation shall establish procedures for the reporting of such conditions, and those procedures shall be specified in the MOE."

issues.submission_excerpt: The Quality Manager is the person responsible for processing Safety Occurrence Report Form received from personnel. The Quality Manager shall investigate maintenance error occurrences and provide a written report to the Accountable Manager and Maintenance Manager.
issues.explanation: The submission names the Quality Manager as responsible for processing and investigating occurrences but does not define the required qualification criteria, the clear authority to coordinate airworthiness occurrence actions or to initiate follow-up investigations, nor does it identify a single focal point to act to the accountable manager when multiple persons are involved. This is less specific than AMC1 which expects assignment of suitably qualified persons with clearly defined authority and a single focal point where applicable.
issues.legislation_source: AMC1 145.A.60 (b) and (c): organisation should assign responsibility to one or more suitably qualified persons with clearly defined authority, for coordinating action on airworthiness occurrences and for initiating any necessary further investigation and follow-up activity; if more than one person is assigned, the organisation should identify a single person to act as the main focal point for ensuring that a single reporting channel is established to the accountable manager.

issues.submission_excerpt: The Quality Manager will maintain a record of Safety Occurrence Report forms received.
issues.explanation: The statement that the Quality Manager will retain records does not demonstrate that the organisation has 'established and maintain[ed] an internal occurrence reporting system as specified in point 145.A.202'. The MOE does not reference 145.A.202 nor show that the system meets the specific requirements referenced by 145.A.60(b) (e.g. scope, interfaces, data handling and required system features), so compliance with the referenced point is not evidenced.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.60(b): "The organisation shall establish and maintain an internal occurrence reporting system as specified in point 145.A.202." (requirement to meet the detailed specification in 145.A.202)

issues.submission_excerpt: Personnel shall report occurrences within 72 hours of becoming aware of the occurrence, unless exceptional circumstances prevent this.
issues.explanation: Requiring personnel to report within 72 hours may permit delay and is ambiguous relative to the requirement that reports be made 'within the time periods specified in Regulation (EU) No 376/2014' (which requires reporting 'as soon as possible and no later than 72 hours' for certain occurrences). The procedure risks delaying upstream reporting to the competent authority because internal notification windows are not aligned to the 'as soon as possible' expectation and there is no clear instruction to immediately escalate occurrences that require prompt regulatory notification.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.60(c): "Reports shall be made within the time periods specified in Regulation (EU) No 376/2014 and in the implementing acts adopted by the Commission, and in a format established by the competent authority." (Regulation (EU) No 376/2014 requires occurrences to be reported as soon as possible and no later than 72 hours where applicable.)

issues.submission_excerpt: The Organization will carry out aircraft and aircraft component maintenance activities for which it is approved in a manner to ensure compliance with Part 145. In performing these activities the following commitments are made: - The principals of human factors with regards to the prevention of human error, accurate communication, teamwork and situational awareness shall be an integral part of the work process when work/orders are being progressed under the terms of the Part 145 approval - A non-punitive maintenance error/incident reporting system is available to all personnel To ensure the economic success of the Organization, safety shall be the prime consideration at all times - It is the duty of all personnel to comply with the necessary procedures, quality standards and regulations All personnel will co-operate with the Organization Quality Authority - Personnel shall not allow commercial imperatives to reduce safety standards - Personnel shall ensure good use of the provided resources. Particular attention shall be made to ensure maintenance work/orders are performed right the first time - All personnel shall maintain an awareness of human factors via the organization’s continuous training programme
issues.explanation: The policy text as presented documents commitments but does not include an explicit statement that the safety and quality policy is included in the MOE and/or that it is formally endorsed (signed) by the Accountable Manager as required. 145.A.65(a) requires the safety and quality policy to be included in the MOE and endorsed by the accountable manager; the submission provides the policy content but no clear endorsement/inclusion record.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.65(a): "The organisation shall establish a safety and quality policy for the organisation to be included in the MOE... The safety and quality policy shall be endorsed by the accountable manager."

issues.submission_excerpt: - He is responsible for preparing standard practices and procedures (MOE, including the associated procedure(s) for use within the organization and ensuring their adequacy regarding Part 145 and any amendments to the Regulation.
issues.explanation: The submission assigns preparation and submission of procedures to the Quality Manager but does not define a process to verify and validate procedures and changes prior to use. AMC1 145.A.65(2) requires that all procedures, and changes to those procedures, should be verified and validated before use where practicable; the MOE must therefore show the verification/validation steps, acceptance criteria and responsible personnel which are not documented here.
issues.legislation_source: AMC1 145.A.65 (2): "All procedures, and changes to those procedures, should be verified and validated before use where practicable and applicable."

issues.submission_excerpt: Initial HF training is carried out using an online provider acceptable to the Quality Manager. The Quality Manager will review the syllabus and ensure it meets the content of GM145.A.30 (e).
issues.explanation: The MOE documents human factors training but does not demonstrate that maintenance procedures themselves are designed and presented in accordance with good human factors principles, nor that maintenance personnel are involved in procedure design/changes. AMC1 145.A.65(3) and GM1 require procedures to be designed/presented using HF principles (usable format, simplified English, clear order/critical steps) and to involve maintenance personnel in the design/changes; the submission does not show how procedures meet these HF design requirements or the involvement/validation by end-users.
issues.legislation_source: AMC1 145.A.65 (3): "All procedures should be designed and presented in accordance with good human factors principles." GM1 145.A.65 (a),(g),(h),(i): involvement of maintenance personnel, order of tasks/critical steps, consistency of terminology, and use of simplified English.

issues.submission_excerpt: *EASA Form 4 Holder
issues.explanation: The MOE must list the title(s) and name(s) of the persons nominated under 145.A.30(b),(c),(ca). Section 1.3 contains only a placeholder "*EASA Form 4 Holder" and does not provide the required names/titles of nominated persons, so the MOE does not meet the explicit content requirement of 145.A.70(a)(3).
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.70 (a)(3): 'the title(s) and name(s) of the persons nominated under point 145.A.30(b), (c) and (ca)'

issues.submission_excerpt:
## 1.5 MANAGEMENT ORGANISATION CHART

*EASA Form 4 Holder
issues.explanation: The regulation requires the MOE to include an organisation chart showing chains of responsibility between the nominated persons. Section 1.5 contains only a placeholder and no actual chart or chain-of-responsibility diagram, leaving roles and reporting lines ambiguous and therefore non-compliant with 145.A.70(a)(5).
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.70 (a)(5): 'an organisation chart showing associated chains of responsibility between the persons referred to in point (3)'

issues.submission_excerpt: A list of certifying staff is held and maintained by the Quality Manager. This list is approved by the Quality Manager and forwarded to the Authority as described in section 1.11 of this MOE.
issues.explanation: 145.A.70(a)(6) requires the MOE to contain a list of certifying and support staff with their scope of authorisation. The MOE text states the list is 'held and maintained' externally by the Quality Manager and forwarded to the Authority, but does not include the actual list or the scopes of authorisation within the MOE itself, so the MOE content is incomplete versus the requirement.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.70 (a)(6): 'a list of certifying staff and support staff, and, if applicable, airworthiness review staff, with their scope of authorisation;'

issues.submission_excerpt: At this time the Company does not have a capability list as no Part 145 C ratings are held.
issues.explanation: 145.A.70(a)(8) requires the MOE to specify the organisation's scope of work relevant to the terms of approval. The MOE explicitly states there is no capability list and does not otherwise provide a clear, approved specification of scope (types, ratings or limits). This omission fails to meet the requirement to specify the scope of work in the MOE and creates ambiguity about what work is approved.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.70 (a)(8): 'a specification of the scope of work relevant to the terms of approval;' (AMC1 145.A.70 (a) (PART 1) (1.9) - 'Organisation’s intended scope of work')

issues.submission_excerpt: At this time the Organization does not maintain a list of suppliers or subcontractors.
issues.explanation: 145.A.70(a)(13) requires, if applicable, a list of organisations to which maintenance tasks are transferred and procedures for control of such organisations. The MOE admits no supplier/subcontractor list and further states supplier files are not maintained, so the MOE lacks the required lists and documentary control of subcontracted organisations, which is a clear non-compliance and a safety/traceability risk.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.70 (a)(13): 'if applicable, a list of the organisations to which the organisation transfers maintenance tasks in accordance with point 145.A.47(c), and the procedures for the control of such organisations;' (see also AMC1 145.A.70 (a) (PART 2) (2.1) Supplier evaluation and subcontractor control procedure)

issues.submission_excerpt: Minor amendments to the Exposition may be made and approved by the Quality Manager without prior approval by the Authority. Minor amendments are detailed in section 1.10 of this Exposition. Indirect approval is recorded in section 0.2 of this Exposition.
issues.explanation: 145.A.70(c) requires that amendments to the MOE be approved by the competent authority, with a derogation only if the competent authority has specifically approved the organisation to self-approve minor amendments. The MOE claims the Quality Manager may approve minor amendments but provides no criteria defining 'minor', no visible section 1.10 (referenced content is missing), no record of competent authority approval to delegate this function, and no proven indirect-approval record. This contradicts the legislative requirement and is therefore non-compliant and ambiguous.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.70 (c): 'The organisation shall establish a procedure for the amendment of the MOE. Amendments to the MOE shall be approved by the competent authority. By way of derogation, the organisation may be approved by the competent authority to approve minor amendments to the MOE.'

issues.submission_excerpt: He is responsible for implementing a quality audit programme in which compliance with all maintenance procedures is reviewed at regular intervals in relation to each type of aircraft (or component) maintained (including the management and completion of audits and production of audit reports). He will ensure that any observed non-compliances or poor standards are brought to the attention of the Maintenance Manager.
issues.explanation: While the MOE assigns responsibility for a quality audit programme, it does not include a defined, documented compliance monitoring scheme (audit plan, frequency, scope, procedures for product audits and for audit findings/corrective action closure) as described in AMC1 (3.8.1–3.8.3). The absence of a formal audit plan and corrective-action procedure in the MOE means the organisation has not fully specified how it will ensure and demonstrate ongoing compliance with the Annex.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.70 (a)(11): 'the procedures specifying how the organisation ensures compliance with this Annex;' and AMC1 145.A.70 (a) (PART 3) (3.8): 'Compliance monitoring' including (3.8.1) 'Audit plan and audit procedures', (3.8.2) 'Product audit and inspections', (3.8.3) 'Audit findings — corrective action procedure'.

issues.submission_excerpt: At this time the Organization does not maintain a list of suppliers or subcontractors.
issues.explanation: AMC1 requires the MOE to contain a specific procedure for the control of subcontractors and a list of subcontractors as part of the authorisation to subcontract. The submission explicitly states no list is maintained, so the MOE does not meet the requirement to include an approved subcontractor list and specific control procedure for subcontracting.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.75(b): organisation may arrange maintenance at another organisation under its management system only limited to scope/procedures in 145.A.47(c) and 145.A.65(b). AMC1 145.A.75(b)(3)(3.6): 'Authorisation to sub-contract is indicated by the competent authority approving the MOE containing a specific procedure on the control of subcontractors as well as a list of subcontractors.'

issues.submission_excerpt: NAA certified suppliers and International Standard accredited suppliers would automatically be acceptable without further assessment.
issues.explanation: AMC1 requires a pre-audit procedure performed under the compliance monitoring function to determine whether a prospective subcontractor meets Part-145 intent. Automatically accepting suppliers/ subcontractors without further assessment or pre-audit is weaker than the AMC and provides no assurance the subcontractor meets Part-145 requirements.
issues.legislation_source: AMC1 145.A.75(b)(4)(4.1): 'A pre-audit procedure should be established whereby the Part-145 organisation should audit a prospective subcontractor ... This audit should be performed under the responsibility of the compliance monitoring function.' AMC1 145.A.75(b)(4)(4.6): 'The Part-145 compliance monitoring staff will need to audit the subcontractor control function ... and to audit the subcontractors.'

issues.submission_excerpt: Apart from the details recorded on the purchase order, the Organization does not retain supplier or subcontractor information.
issues.explanation: AMC1 requires the subcontractor control procedure to ensure records of all subcontractor audits/inspections and corresponding actions are kept, to include a clear revocation process, and contracts must provide authority access. The submission states minimal retention (purchase order only) and no files, indicating absence of required records, revocation process and contractual clauses for authority access.
issues.legislation_source: AMC1 145.A.75(b)(4)(4.5): 'The procedure should ensure that records of all subcontractor audits and inspections, and the corresponding actions are kept, and provide information on when subcontractors are used. The procedure should include a clear revocation process for subcontractors ...' AMC1 145.A.75(b)(4)(4.7): 'The contract ... should contain a provision to ensure that access to the subcontractor is granted to any person authorised by the authorities specified in point 145.A.140.'

issues.submission_excerpt: A certificate of release to service shall be issued by appropriately authorised certifying staff on behalf of the Organization when it has been verified that all maintenance ordered has been properly carried out by the Organization ...
issues.explanation: AMC1 permits subcontractor staff to issue CRS only when a certification authorisation has been issued by the Part-145 organisation in accordance with 145.A.30/145.A.35. The submission states CRS will be issued by 'appropriately authorised certifying staff' but contains no procedure describing how subcontractor personnel would be authorised, controlled, or how the Part-145 organisation will ensure those subcontractor staff meet the Part-145 authorisation requirements.
issues.legislation_source: AMC1 145.A.75(b)(4)(4.4): 'The certificate of release to service may be issued either by subcontractor staff holding a certification authorisation issued by the Part-145 organisation in accordance with points 145.A.30 and 145.A.35 as appropriate, or by the Part-145 organisation certifying staff.' (See also requirements in 145.A.30 and 145.A.35 regarding certifying staff authorisations.)

issues.submission_excerpt: The Organization may maintain any aircraft or any component for which it is approved at any location subject to the need for such maintenance arising either from the unserviceability of the aircraft or from the necessity of supporting occasional line maintenance, subject to the procedure specified in section 2.24.1 of this Exposition;
issues.explanation: The excerpt allows maintenance at any location subject to an internal procedure (section 2.24.1) but does not state that the organisation will notify the competent authority of any proposal to add or change additional locations prior to the change, as required by 145.A.80(3). Relying on an internal procedure without explicitly requiring prior notification to the Authority creates an ambiguity and risk of non‑compliance if section 2.24.1 does not contain the mandated notification steps.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.80(3): "the organisation shall notify the competent authority of any proposal to carry out... (3) additional locations of the organisation" (requirement to notify CA before such changes take place)

issues.submission_excerpt: The Organization may maintain any aircraft and/or component for which it is approved at a location identified as a line maintenance location capable of supporting minor maintenance; where established and approved by the Authority, these locations are detailed section 5.3 of this Exposition.
issues.explanation: The text indicates locations may be 'established and approved by the Authority' but does not explain how the organisation will notify the Authority of changes to facilities, equipment, tools, material, procedures, scope of work or certifying staff that could affect the terms of approval, nor that such notification will occur before changes. This absence fails to demonstrate compliance with 145.A.80(6) and leaves unclear who initiates amendments to the approval/certificate.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.80(6): "the organisation shall notify the competent authority of any proposal to carry out... (6) the facilities, equipment, tools, material, procedures, scope of work or certifying staff that could affect the terms of approval" (notification required before changes)

issues.submission_excerpt: ## 1.9 SCOPE OF WORK
issues.explanation: Within the provided 'Scope of Work' content there is no statement or procedure describing notification to the competent authority prior to changes to the accountable manager (145.A.80(4)) or to persons nominated under 145.A.30(b),(c),(ca) (145.A.80(5)). The absence of any reference to how or when such personnel changes will be communicated to the Authority is a clear omission versus the legislation's explicit prior‑notification requirement.
issues.legislation_source: 145.A.80(4) and (5): "the organisation shall notify the competent authority of any proposal to carry out... (4) the accountable manager; (5) any of the persons nominated under point 145.A.30(b), (c) and (ca)" (notification required before changes)
